Thanksgiving Retreats.description: The Abhayagiri Monastic Thanksgiving retreat was traditionally an annual ten-day residential retreat held at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa, California during the week of Thanksgiving. However, after the Angela Center closed due to fire damage in 2017 and the COVID pandemic began in 2020, the location, date, duration, and format of this retreat have varied significantly.

Abhayagiri Winter Retreats.description: During the months of January, February, and March, the resident community of Abhayagiri Monastery ceases all non-essential work to practice meditation. There are usually Dhamma readings nearly every day, some of which end with questions and answers regarding the teachings.

Spirit Rock Meditation Center.address: 5000 Sir Francis Drake Blvd., PO Box 169, Woodacre, CA 94973

Quote.usageNotes: A quote from the teacher him/herself.

Indirect quote.usageNotes: The teacher quoting someone else. If the person quoted in a teacher, they should get the first tag.
form: ++Quote:++ @!prefix!@ “@!text!@”@!' — ' if suffix else ''!@@!suffix!@||@!'.' if suffix else ''!@ Quoted by @!teachers!@.

Reading.usageNotes: {teachers} should be the author(s) of the book. Use a Read by annotation to indicate who does the reading. If the book appears in the list of references, {teachers} will be set and " by {teachers}" inserted automatically. If not, plug both in manually along with the hyperlink if relevant.

Read by.usageNotes: If the reader is not a teacher, {teachers} should be Anon and {text} specifies the name of the reader.
form: @!'Read by ' if text else ''!@@!text!@@!'.' if text else ''!@||Read by @!teachers!@.
body: @!'Read by ' if text else ''!@@!text!@@!'.' if text else ''!@{attribution}

SRD2010.title: Recollections of Ajahn Chah
SRD2010.subtitle: His Life and Teachings
SRD2010.description: During this daylong retreat, Ajahn Pasanno shares teachings and memories of his beloved teacher, Ajahn Chah. By the time of his passing in 1992, Ajahn Chah had become one of the most highly revered Buddhist meditation masters in Thailand.

annotations.text: Stillness Flowing p. 40
annotations.body: Reference: Stillness Flowing by Ajahn Jayasaro p. 40

annotations.text: I dedicate my body and mind, my whole life, to the practice of the Lord Buddha’s teachings in their entirety. I will realize the truth in this lifetime … I will let go of everything and follow the teachings. No matter how much suffering and difficulty I have to endure I will persevere, otherwise there will be no end to my doubts. I will make this life as even and continuous as a single day and night. I will abandon attachments to mind and body and follow the Buddha’s teachings until I know their truth for myself.|Ajahn Chah
annotations.body: Quote: “I dedicate my body and mind, my whole life, to the practice of the Lord Buddha’s teachings in their entirety. I will realize the truth in this lifetime … I will let go of everything and follow the teachings. No matter how much suffering and difficulty I have to endure I will persevere, otherwise there will be no end to my doubts. I will make this life as even and continuous as a single day and night. I will abandon attachments to mind and body and follow the Buddha’s teachings until I know their truth for myself.” — Ajahn Chah

excerpts.text: For Lent, I practiced metta every day for six weeks for a person who I was very angry at. By the end of Lent, I was even more angry. Could you speak to this?

excerpts.text: I travelled for six weeks in Thailand and India and found that time really shifted. Having been home about two months, even with a daily meditation practice, time speeds up. How is life at the monastery versus tudong, and what do you have to say to laypeople about the speeding up of time?

excerpts.text: It all comes back to that simple quality of mindfulness. From the mindfulness, then the different qualities of practice that we need to rely on are cultivated.

annotations.text: The base and foundation is the mindfulness. Being the knowing is always the foundation, and then the mind is able to become still, become settled, become steady.
annotations.body: Quote: “The base and foundation is the mindfulness. Being the knowing is always the foundation, and then the mind is able to become still, become settled, become steady.”

annotations.text: "It's rare that Ajahn Chah would use [the Pāli term] pañña on its own. More often than not, he would use satipañña, which is mindfulness and wisdom together."
annotations.body: Recollection: "It's rare that Ajahn Chah would use [the Pāli term] pañña on its own. More often than not, he would use satipañña, which is mindfulness and wisdom together."

excerpts.body: Quote: “It all comes back to that simple quality of mindfulness. From the mindfulness, then the different qualities of practice that we need to rely on are cultivated.” {attribution}
